story:
Once upon a time, in a lush and vibrant village in Africa, there lived a kind and curious young girl named Ada. Ada had a deep love for nature and all of its wonders, and she spent much of her time exploring the forests and savannas that surrounded her home.

One day, as Ada was wandering through the woods, she came across a small, injured bird. The bird had a broken wing and was unable to fly. Ada knew that she had to help, so she gently picked up the bird and carried it back to her village.

Word quickly spread of Ada's kindness, and soon the entire village was buzzing with excitement. The village elder, a wise old woman named Nana, heard of Ada's good deed and decided to reward her by sharing a secret with her.

"Ada, my child," Nana said, "you have a kind and gentle spirit, and the animals of the forest know this. There is a magical tree deep in the forest, and if you can find it, you will be granted a special gift."

Ada was determined to find the magical tree and claim her gift. She set out early the next morning, armed with nothing but a small bag of seeds and a determined heart.

After many hours of walking, Ada finally came upon the magical tree. It was taller and more majestic than any tree she had ever seen, and its leaves shimmered in the sunlight.

As Ada approached the tree, it spoke to her in a soft, gentle voice.

"Welcome, Ada," the tree said. "You have proven yourself to be a true friend to the animals, and for that, I will grant you a special gift."

The tree then sprinkled a handful of magical seeds at Ada's feet.

"Plant these seeds, Ada," the tree said, "and watch as they grow into a beautiful garden. This garden will provide food and shelter for all of the animals, and they will always remember your kindness."

Ada thanked the tree and planted the seeds. Over the next few weeks, a beautiful garden grew, filled with fruits, vegetables, and flowers of every color. The animals of the forest flocked to the garden, and they all lived in harmony.

From that day on, Ada was known as the guardian of the forest. She spent her days tending to the garden and helping the animals. And every night, as she lay in bed, she would smile as she remembered the magical tree and the special gift it had given her.

The end.

As a parent, you can add your own twist to the story and also make it interactive by asking your child questions about the story, for example, "What do you think Ada should do when she finds the injured bird?" or "What kind of seeds do you think Ada should plant in her garden?" This will make the story more engaging and fun for your child.
